It doesn't seem to be a standard practice, although I don't know why.  Usually kodogu is just displayed for study.  We did tsuba kantei a couple of times in the NY club.  I made a small wooden clamp that would cover up the seppa dai but still allow the tsuba to be picked up.  I haven't seen it done elsewhere.  Doing kantei kai of mumei items is a little problematic since the "right" answer is still an opinion rather than a fact.

Doing it online has the handicap of not being able to see everything about the piece, but of course that's true too of paper kantei contests for swords.  It could be done if someone has the time.  It'd be easy enough to Photoshop out signatures.

Jim



  Greeting's all. I guess this question may be directed to Jim more than
  anyone else, but I am sure others will be more than keen to jump in if
  they feel so inclined.

  Are there ever any or many Tsuba or Tosogu Kantei ? I am sure there are
  at group/club meetings and such but I was thinking more in line with the
  Nihonto Kantei the NTHK offer in their monthly or Kenji Mishina offers
  on-line.

  The recent post's in regards to David and Curran's guards, with the
  answers that ensued, got me thinking it would be great to see maybe 1/2
  a dozen tsuba offered up each month for kantei. I guess the usual
  aspects of kantei would remain the same, i.e. style, type of work, size,
  thickness, tekkotsu if there and either an image with the mei ( if
  applicable ) hidden or some sort.

  Just a thought, sounds like fun to me :-)

  any thought's on this ?

  Cheers

  Rich.
